block.p: Palestinians Ambush Bus, Killing 7 and Wounding 17 Gunmen in Israeli Army uniforms set off a roadside bomb near a bus approaching a Jewish settlement in the West Bank, then hurled grenades and raked the vehicle with gunfire, killing 7 people and wounding 17 before escaping. One of the suspects in the attack was later killed in a gun battle with Israeli troops, military officials said.

Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and top envoys from the United Nations, the European Union and Russia, meeting in New York, agreed on the broad goal of creating a Palestinian state within three years, but differed sharply on almost everything else, including the role of Yasir Arafat.

India Presses U.S. on Pakistan The Indian government, under increasing domestic political pressure for a tough response to a deadly attack Saturday night in Jammu and Kashmir, renewed its call for the United States to declare Pakistan a terrorist state for failing to dismantle a ''terrorist infrastructure.''

The I.R.A. Apologizes The guerrillas issued their first unmitigated apology to the relatives of the 650 or so civilians killed in its violent 30-year effort to unite Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic.

British Leader Grilled Prime Minister Tony Blair, combating accusations that he has taken on presidential airs and given short shrift to Parliament, fielded questions for two and a half hours from a panel from the House of Commons. It was the first such interrogation of a prime minister in British history.
Bush Selects Envoy to Mexico President Bush said he would nominate Antonio O. Garza, 43, a former Texas secretary of state and political ally, as ambassador to Mexico.
Turkey Plans Early Elections The ailing prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, agreed to early elections, in November, after six new defections brought his wobbly coalition below a majority in Parliament.

U.P.S. and Teamsters Agree on 25% Raises The United Parcel Service said it had reached a tentative six-year pact that would give 210,000 Teamsters a 25 percent increase in wages and benefits. The deal, the biggest test for the Teamsters' president, James P. Hoffa, covers more workers than any other private-sector union contract in the nation.

States Press Bush on Climate The attorneys general of 11 states asked President Bush for strong federal measures to limit emissions of so-called greenhouse gases, saying a ''regulatory void'' had left a patchwork of inconsistent state regulations for protecting the environment.

Terror Arrests in Spain The Spanish police arrested three men suspected of being operatives of Al Qaeda, and officials said one had five-year-old videotapes with hours of surveillance images of the World Trade Center and other possible terror targets in the United States.

The Sept. 11 hijackers pumped hundreds of thousands of dollars into commercial banks but never tripped any of the alarms designed to warn regulators of suspicious movements of cash, investigators said.
President Bush's new plan for domestic security won praise but also raised concerns that some provisions could undermine civil liberties.

Charity Under Investigation A federal grand jury is investigating how the United Way chapter in Washington, D.C., spent donations. The inquiry comes four months after the charity said a special audit had found nothing significant amiss with its finances or management.
Girl Kidnapped From Street A 5-year-old girl was abducted kicking and screaming outside her apartment in Stanton, Calif., by a man who drove up and asked for help finding his dog, the police said.

Children and Working Mothers A new analysis of the largest government child-care study found that early maternal employment had negative effects on children's intellectual development. Other reports using the same data have found no link between long hours in child care and lower scores on school-readiness tests.

Ex-Officer Guilty of Perjury; No Verdict on Other Counts A federal jury convicted Charles Schwarz on one of two perjury counts in connection with the Abner Louima assault, but jurors in his retrial deadlocked on three other charges. Prosecutors will seek to retry him on those charges. He remains free on bond pending sentencing on Sept. 20.

Lower Manhattan Visions Six design proposals for the World Trade Center site were unveiled, but the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation asked that the public also consider a seventh: a blank slate, without many of the requirements for office and retail space that drove the six designs.

Fatal Boat Crash Inquiry Investigators said a boat struck by another in Little Neck Bay on Thursday night, killing two people, carried a knapsack containing four bags of cocaine. Officials were also looking at whether the boat had its lights on.

Williams's Will Not Last Word Ted Williams's will was filed in a Florida court and although it stated that he wanted to be cremated, the executor of his estate said that Williams had changed his mind and wanted to be cryonically frozen.

Iverson Surrenders to Police The Philadelphia 76ers' star guard Allen Iverson pleaded not guilty to breaking into an apartment with a gun in his waistband and making threats while looking for his wife.
The Red Wine Headache An article in the Harvard Health Letter says headaches triggered by drinking red wine are ''a real if poorly understood phenomenon.''

'Infectious Greed' The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, told senators that a corporate culture blighted by ''infectious greed'' had caused the breakdown in confidence among investors. The House hurriedly passed a measure with criminal fraud penalties that lawmakers said were even tougher than those passed by the Senate.
The Dow lost 166.08 points, or 1.9 percent, to 8,473.11. The Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500 also lost ground.

Intel Offers Grim Outlook The world's largest microchip manufacturer said it had encountered few signs of economic recovery in the second quarter and that it expected weaker-than-normal seasonal improvement in demand. It will move to cut costs and 4,000 jobs.
Deutsche Telekom Chief Out Ron Sommer resigned from the company he had sought to transform from a state monopoly into a global communications colossus. Helmut Sihler, 72, will be interim chief.
Editorials: The downtown we don't want; Dr. Greenspan's prescription; a master plan for homeland security; Indonesia's unreformed military.
